Description: small and very slender whaler
ranges from bronze to grey on the upper surface and pale underneath
distinguished by a very large eye with a distinct rear notch.
small, slender to moderately stout whaler
ranges from yellowish to bronze on the upper surface and pale underneath
distinguished from other whalers by a distinct black tip on the second dorsal fin and no other obvious markings.
very large oceanic whaler with large, broadly rounded dorsal and pectoral fins
bronze-grey on the upper surface and pale underneath
juveniles have black saddle markings before the second dorsal and caudal fin, usually a black mark on the upper caudal fin, and black tips on most fins
black markings fade to white mottled tips in specimens above 130 cm
upper teeth are erect, broadly triangular and serrated.
medium to large, slender whaler
ranges from grey to bronze on the upper surface and pale underneath
usually black fin tips in specimens over 100 cm and dusky or no markings on smaller specimens
distinct long, hard and pointed snout and very small erect teeth.
Frequent misidentifications: species (milk shark, grey sharpnose shark and Australian sharpnose shark).
Other names: Longnose grey whaler, longnose whaler, longnose grey shark, inkytail shark, smoothfang shark

Description: medium to large, slender to moderately stout whaler
upper body bronze (brown or grey after death) with a pale stripe along the flanks and pale underneath
conspicuous white tips on first dorsal, pectoral and upper caudal fins (sometimes indistinct on small specimens, especially after death).
Fisheries: Gillnet and line fisheries, however rarely encountered.
Distribution: associated with coral reefs north of Brisbane on the east coast and north of Port Headland on the west coast
known specimens observed in north-eastern Gulf of Carpentaria.

Description: medium-sized whaler
has a stockier build and a blunter snout than
C. tilstoni, C. limbatus
and
C. brevipinna
upper body bronze to grey with a pale thin stripe extending along the flank and white underneath
most fins with black tips but anal fin sometimes pale
flanks can be slimy to touch
Distribution: north of Brisbane on the east coast and Carnarvon on the west

Description: large and moderately stout whaler
ranges from pale yellow to light brown or grey on the upper surface and pale underneath
broad, rounded or obtusely wedge-shaped snout and relatively small eyes
flanks can be rough to touch.
Fisheries: Gillnet and line fisheries; more common in inshore gillnet fisheries.
Other names: Sharptooth lemon shark, sharptooth shark, sicklefin lemon shark

Description: small slender whaler
bronze on the upper surface and pale underneath
pale stripe along the flanks
distinguished by location of origin of second dorsal fin behind origin of anal fin.
Rhizoprionodon spp.
and
Loxodon macrorhinus
share this feature, however the hardnose shark has almost erect upper teeth with strong serrations basally while the other species have oblique upper teeth without strong serrations.
both moderately slender, medium-sized whalers
range from bronze to dark grey on the upper surface and white to yellow underneath
black tips on all but the anal fin (becoming indistinct in adults) and a pale stripe extending along the flank
only readily distinguished by DNA analysis or vertebral counts which are higher in
C. limbatus
(precaudal vertebrae counts = 94-102) than in
C. tilstoni
(precaudal vertebrae counts = 84-91).
Frequent misidentifications: are commonly confused with one another (the published ratios of
in the Arafura Sea is 300:1 but 15:55 off northeast Queensland; however preliminary genetics results from the east coast suggest that

make
          up more of the population than estimated previously)
Fisheries: inshore and offshore gillnet and line fisheries
is the most common species taken in the Gulf of Carpentaria offshore gillnet fishery.
Other names: Blacktip whaler, blacktip shark, blacktip shark complex.

Description: small to medium, moderately stout whaler
distinguished by distinct white tips on the first dorsal and upper caudal fins, and sometimes on the second dorsal and lower caudal fins
upper body brown to grey, usually with scattered dark spots and cream underneath
flanks can be very coarse to touch.
Fisheries: rarely encountered in the Gulf of Carpentaria but occasionally in east coast fisheries.

Description: medium sized, moderately stout whaler
has a large second dorsal fin (at least half the height of the first dorsal fin)
grey on the upper surface and pale underneath with an inconspicuous pale stripe along the flanks.
Protected species: Speartooth sharks are protected throughout Queensland and are therefore prohibited from being in anyone's possession without a permit.
Fisheries: Inshore gillnet fisheries; however, rarely encountered.
Frequent misidentification: Northern river shark/New Guinea river shark (
Distribution: Inshore including estuaries and river systems in the northern Gulf of Carpentaria and eastern coastline of Queensland. Captures reported in the southern and western gulf are unconfirmed.
Other names: Blue, Bizant, Queensland or Northern river shark,

Description: both small, slender whalers, similar to the milk shark (
R. acutus
) but with smaller labial furrows confined to the corners of the mouth
distinguished from each other by the number of hyomandibular pores (
R. oligolinx
with three to eight pores either side of mouth, and
R. taylori
with seven to 11)
also differentiated through precaudal vertebral counts (
R. oligolinx
with 84-91 precaudal vertebra and
R. taylori
with only 73-81).
Frequent misidentifications: Confused with each other and also with the milk shark (
Fisheries: Trawl, gillnet and line fisheries, however rarely encountered.
Distribution: mainly found in Gulf of Carpentaria.
Other names: is also referred to as Taylor's shark.

Description: small to medium stout whaler
ranges from yellowish-bronze to grey on the upper surface and white underneath
a white stripe extends along the flank.
black tips to lower caudal (and sometimes pectoral) fins, and dark margins on front edges of dorsal, pectoral and upper caudal fins and back edge of caudal fin.
Fisheries: Inshore and occasionally offshore gillnet fishery.
Distribution: Inshore/offshore, but more commonly reported inshore.

Description: large slender and elongated whaler
ranges from bluish-black to dark brown or grey on the upper surface and white underneath
sometimes has dusky tips on the pectoral, second dorsal and anal fins.

Fisheries: May interact with trawl and net fisheries.
Description: Generally small (up to 107 cm), slender bottom dwelling sharks characterised by blunt, bulbous heads with short nasal barbels and a long tail.
Adult grey carpetsharks are brown or grey and the juveniles (up to 30cm) have wavy lines or small dark spots.
The epaulette shark is yellow-brown with well-spaced brown spots. There is one large white-edged black spot on each flank behind the gill slits.
The speckled carpetshark is yellowish with closely spaced fine brown spots. There is a large white-edged black spot on each flank behind the gill slits, flanked by dark blotches behind.

name: Longtail carpetsharks - three species encountered in Queensland waters

Description: small, moderately slender shark
long, moderately rounded snout and moderately long nasal lobes
light bronze to greyish brown above and pale underneath
second dorsal and upper caudal fin tips dark, fading in larger specimens
distinguished from
H. elongata
in that the teeth don't protrude readily from the mouth.
medium sized, slender to moderately stout whaler
upper body grey-brown to grey and white underneath
a prominent black margin on the back of the tail fin (less distinct in large specimens).
Fisheries: rarely encountered in the Gulf of Carpentaria but occasionally in east coast fisheries.
Distribution: Inshore/offshore, associated with reefs and shoals.
Size: 50 to 180 cm, reported up to 255 cm.

Description: large, moderately slender shark
similar to the scalloped hammerhead shark but distinguished by its well arched hammer with no central indentation
olive to grey-brown above and white below with dusky tips to ventral fins
no central indentation on hammer of
S. zygaena,
unlike
S lewini
Distribution: Inshore/offshore, only in South East Queensland (south of Fraser Island).

Scientific name: Bigeye thresher - Alopias superciliosus. CAAB code: 37 012002.
Description: Thresher sharks are:
blue-grey above and white underneath with white extending above pectoral fin bases
the most commonly caught thresher in Australian waters
teeth are similar to the bigeye thresher, but smaller.
The bigeye thresher shark:
purple to violet-grey above and creamy white underneath with very large eyes and distinct grooves on top of the head
not frequently caught in Australian waters
the teeth are relatively large, with the cusps long, slender, smooth edged and without lateral cusplets
the teeth are almost erect at the front of the mouth but oblique to the sides and back.
Size: Thresher sharks range from 115 to 550 cm, while bigeye thresher sharks range from 100 to 460 cm.

name: Thresher sharks - two species encountered in Queensland waters

Fisheries: Occasionally in line fisheries and rarely as bycatch in trawl fisheries.
Description: Highly diverse group of small elongated shallow and deep water sharks - at least 13 species occur in Queensland waters.
Grey, brown, yellowish or black in colour, often with light or dark spots and dark blotches, bars and saddles.
large, moderately slender shark
distinguished by its broadly arched hammer, with central and deeper side indentations
body brown or bronze to grey above and white below
underside of fin tips grey or black in adults.
Fisheries: most common hammerhead species in offshore gillnet fisheries.

Description: large and moderately stout shark
very short snout and prominently protruding teeth
ranges from light to dark brown on the upper surface and pale below
juveniles commonly have brownish spots.
Protected species: Grey nurse sharks are protected throughout Queensland and are therefore prohibited from being in anyone's possession without a permit.
Fisheries: Trawl, bottom gillnets and line fisheries; however, rarely encountered.
Size: To at least 318 cm, but possibly to 400 cm.

Description: medium sized pelagic shark
very large eyes
long, slender teeth
long gill slits extending onto the top of the head.
very large, stout shark
ranges from light to dark grey or brown on the upper surface and white underneath
black tips on underside of pectoral fins and sometimes a dark spot on pectoral fin axils.
Protected species: Great white sharks are protected throughout Queensland and are therefore prohibited from being in anyone's possession without a permit.
Frequent misidentifications: Juveniles have slender teeth and so may be confused with shortfin mako (

Description: small to medium, moderately slender shark
distinguished by its very long and slender hammer
body brown to grey above and white below
no distinct fin markings.

Fisheries: Occasionally in line fisheries and rarely as bycatch in trawl fisheries.
Description: Small to medium-sized slender sharks, bronze to grey-brown above and pale below.
The first dorsal fin is always located in front of the pelvic fin (like the whalers and weasel sharks), but hound sharks lack precaudal pits and have a spiral-shaped intestinal valve.
large, moderately slender shark
distinguished by its moderately arched hammer (in young but straight in adults), with central and shallow side indentations
brown to grey above and pale below
underside of fin tips grey or black in adults.
large, moderately slender shark
indigo-blue on the upper surface and white underneath
similar sized upper and lower caudal fin lobes (compared to the blue shark where the upper lobe is much longer)
noticeably protruding teeth.
Other names: Mako shark, blue pointer, mackerel shark, snapper shark

Description: medium-sized, moderately slender shark
long, broadly rounded snout
bronze to grey-brown above and pale below
a dark blotch on the second dorsal and upper caudal fins; fading in larger specimens
distinguished from
H. australiensis
by distinct hooked, erect lower teeth that protrude from the mouth when closed.
large ray-like shark
flattened body and extremely broad pectoral fins
yellow-brown to dark brown on the upper surface with small white, dark edged spots and white underneath
only species of angelshark reported from Queensland waters.
Frequent misidentifications: ) which does not occur in Queensland waters.

Description: large guitarfish with a triangular snout
upper surface grey to yellow-brown and pale underneath
larger specimens are darker with less distinct spots.
Distribution: Inshore/offshore, and possibly several species involved.

Description: medium-sized shovelnose ray
has long, narrowly pointed opaque snout
grey brown on the upper surface, sometimes with dark blotches, and white underneath with irregular dark flecks.
Distribution: mainly inshore in lower estuaries and off beaches but also in deeper waters.

Description: Large, relatively stout shark with a very short blunt snout, a small mouth and short nasal barbels. Light brown to grey above and lighter below, sometimes with darker fins, especially at tips. Flanks can be coarse to touch.
Fisheries: Trawl, gillnet and line fisheries, however rarely encountered.
Other names: Tawny nurse shark, sleepy shark, spitting shark, madame X

Potected species: Narrow sawfish are protected throughout Queensland and are therefore prohibited from being in anyone's possession without a permit.
Description: moderately large, slender sawfish
distinguished by absence of teeth around base of saw
grey above and pale below, often with pale fins
smooth to touch.
Fisheries: most common sawfish encountered in offshore fisheries
juveniles found moving along foreshores early in year.
Distribution: most widely distributed and abundant sawfish in Gulf of Carpentaria waters.

Fisheries: May interact with trawl and net fisheries.
Distribution: Demersal in coastal waters south of Mooloolaba.
Description: small (up to 86 cm) slender carpetshark
yellow-brown above and pale below
conspicuous broad, dark collar over the gills
dusky saddles and large dark spots on the body and fins.
distinguished from catsharks in having the mouth well in front of the eyes and with nasoral grooves connecting the mouth and nostrils.
large slender sawfish
green-brown or olive on the upper body and pale below
rough to touch.
Protected species: Green sawfish are protected throughout Queensland and are therefore prohibited from being in anyone's possession without a permit.
Fisheries: Trawl, gillnet and line fisheries; however, rarely encountered.
Distribution: juveniles found inshore in foreshores and embayments
adults found in deeper shelf waters and seasonally inshore.
Size: Generally from 80 to 500 cm (but reported to 700 cm).

Fisheries: Interacts with demersal trawl and gillnet fisheries.
Description: Wobbegongs are small to large (up to 300 cm) bottom-dwelling sharks characterised by a flattened head and body, numerous dermal lobes around the head and elaborate colouration.
The tasselled wobbegong has a dense tassel of dermal lobes around the head. Blotches form a complex mosaic pattern.
The spotted wobbegong has dark saddles superimposed and bordered by white rings and blotches.
A smaller species, the northern wobbegong has three large pale-edged, dark blotches along the back and dark bands under each dorsal fin and above the anal fin.
The banded wobbegong has dark saddles with white rings and blotches highlighted by black edges. There are two supraocular knobs above the eyes and four to six dermal lobes at the preocular group.
The ornate wobbegong is similar to the banded wobbegong but smaller, more freckled and lacking supraocular knobs. There are three (rarely four) dermal lobes at the preocular group.

Fisheries: only species of horn shark known in Queensland waters.
Description: small to medium sized (from 22 to 130 cm) stocky shark
large blunt head and broad dark bars and saddles
distinguished from
H. portusjacksoni
(which occurs in New South Wales) by very high supra-orbital crests ending abruptly behind the eyes.
large, deep bodied guitarfish
horny ridges with enlarged thorns along dorsal midline and near eyes
short and broadly rounded snout
blue-grey on the upper surface, paler towards the snout and pectoral fin margins, and pale underneath
larger specimens are darker with less distinct markings.

Protected species: Freshwater sawfish are protected throughout Queensland and are therefore prohibited from being in anyone's possession without a permit.
Distribution: Relatively uncommon, found in coastal drainages in northern Australia, sometimes along way upstream freshwater creeks.
Description: Large ray-like fish with distinctly saw -like snout, usually with 18 teeth on each side.
Body colour: brown -olive dorsally, white underneath.
very distinctive demersal shark
adults yellow to dark brown with dark brown spots
juveniles dark with white bars and spots above and pale below
albino zebra shark encountered very rarely.
Fisheries: Trawl, gillnet and line fisheries; however, rarely encountered.

Description: Highly diverse group of small to large, slender, deep-water sharks.
Characterised by large eyes (often green) without nictating eyelids, spiracles always present, a spine in front of both dorsal fins, and no anal fin.
Colours vary from pink, brown, greyish or black on the upper body, some with dark or white fin tips, and pale underneath.
At least 12 species may occur in Queensland waters.

Fisheries: Interacts with trawl and net fisheries.
Description: Generally stout, small to medium sized bottom-dwelling sharks similar to the longtail carpetsharks but with longer nasal barbels.
Colclough's shark is a smaller species (to at least 60 cm). It is grey-brown with dark saddles on the body fading in larger specimens. Juveniles have faint dark bands around the body and tail.

The blind shark is a larger species (up to 120 cm), but is rare in Queensland waters. It is light brown to black, usually with pale spots and dark saddles fading in larger specimens. Juveniles have faint dark bands around the body and tail

name: Blind sharks - at least two species encountered in Queensland

Description: large, slender to moderately stout whaler
ranges from bronze to grey or blue-grey on the upper surface and white underneath
has a pale stripe along the flanks
indistinct dusky tips on most fins.
large stout whaler
ranges from pale to dark grey or blue-grey
bold dark markings in juveniles become vertical bars, which fade in larger specimens
distinguished by a long tapered tail and uniquely cockscomb shaped teeth.
small to medium sized whaler
ranges from bronze to grey on the upper surface and pale underneath
no distinct fin markings
characterised by large, broad triangular pectoral fins, a narrow, pointed snout and teeth with a distinct small curvature at the tip.
Fisheries: Inshore and occasionally offshore gillnet fisheries.
Distribution: More commonly encountered inshore but also offshore.

Description: Medium-sized, moderately stout sawfish
Olive to sandy brown above and pale white below, with a broad rostrum that tapers distally
Rough to touch
Protected species: Dwarf sawfish are protected throughout Queensland and are therefore prohibited from being in anyone's possession without a permit.
Fisheries: Very rare encounters and highly variable locations
Distribution: Isolated regions of northern and western, and very few in southern, Gulf of Carpentaria
Juveniles more commonly encountered in coastal foreshores and embayments; adults in marine waters
Size: Up to 150 cm (locally caught at 310 cm)

Description: medium to large stocky whaler
similar to
C. amboinensis
but with the first dorsal fin three times higher than the second dorsal fin (as opposed to four times in
C. amboinensis
light to dark grey on the upper surface and pale underneath
pale stripe along the flanks
juveniles have dusky to black fin tips.
Fisheries: Inshore (and rare large specimens in offshore) gillnet fisheries, and line fisheries.
Distribution: Inshore, including in estuaries and rivers, and offshore.
Other names: River whaler, freshwater whaler, Swan River whaler, Zambezi shark.

Description: medium-sized shovelnose ray
has a broadly triangular, opaque snout
upper body grey-brown to olive with pale to yellow margins on the pectoral, pelvic, dorsal and caudal fins.
Distribution: juveniles inshore (in mangrove systems, estuaries and around coral reefs)

Description: large, moderately stout whaler
characterised by a very tall and erect first dorsal fin, broadly triangular teeth and an interdorsal ridge
ranges from blue-grey to brown-grey or bronze on the upper surface and pale underneath
no distinct fin markings; however the tips and rear margins of pectoral, pelvic and caudal fins may be pale (more so on juveniles).
medium to large, stocky whaler
similar to
C. leucas
but with the first dorsal fin four times the height of the second dorsal fin (as opposed to three times in
C. leucas
) and slimier to touch
has a distinctly acute notch on the anal fin
the front margin of teeth are angled slightly outward.
Fisheries: Trawl, gillnet and line fisheries including inshore river, brackish and offshore netting operations.
Distribution: Inshore (including estuaries and rivers) and offshore.

Description: large very slender whaler
bright indigo-blue on the upper surface and white underneath
similar in colour to
I. oxyrinchus
but with the upper caudal fin much longer than the lower.
Other names: Blue whaler, great blue shark, blue pointer.

Description: small, slender whaler
ranges from bronze to grey on the upper surface and pale underneath
sometimes has a dark margin on the upper caudal fin and pale margins on the ventral fins
distinguished by distinctly long upper labial furrows and oblique upper teeth.
Other names: White-eye shark, Longman's dogshark, fish shark

Fisheries: Occasionally taken by inshore gillnet fisheries, but rarely in the Gulf of Carpentaria.
Descriptions: Small to medium, moderately stout whaler
ranges from yellow-brown to grey on the upper surface and white underneath
pale white stripe running along the flanks
distinct black tips on all fins and a thin black margin on the front of the upper and the back off both caudal fin lobes
can be coarse to touch on flanks.
Distribution: associated with coral reefs and shoals.
Size: 48 to at least 140 cm (possibly to 180 cm).

Description: medium sized, slender whaler
relatively tall and broad based first dorsal fin, long pectoral fins and a prominent interdorsal ridge
upper surface bronze to grey and white underneath
no distinct fin markings, but fin tips sometimes dusky in juveniles
upper teeth triangular, long, pointed and serrated; erect at front of mouth and progressively oblique towards the back.
Frequent misidentifications: - no records in Queensland coastal waters)
Fisheries: Demersal trawl and possibly gillnet and line fisheries; however rarely encountered.
Distribution: offshore, reported off northern Queensland but also possibly southern Queensland
demersal on deep continental shelves and insular slopes by day and may be pelagic by night.

Description: small to medium, slender to moderately stout whaler
ranges from bronze to grey above and white underneath
characterised by a distinct black spot on the tips of the second dorsal, pectoral and lower caudal fins and a distinct interdorsal ridge.
Fisheries: second most common whaler species encountered in the Gulf of Carpentaria offshore gillnet fishery.
